sub_title: Capacity Strenghtening and Professional Support of Faith-base Organisations
summary: We aim to strengthen the capacities of development organisations, focusing on faith-based NGOs, dioceses and religious congregations; and other development actors in sub-Saharan Africa. We provide support to these organisations, so that they can manage, sustain and propagate their development projects professionally, based on result based strategies. We believe that trust, mutual respect and shared values are a strong base for fruitful partnership.

profile_positions.description:
We have many years of experience of working in and with faith-based organisations in Sub-Saharan Africa and in Belgium and in the Netherlands. The combination of our professional knowledge on developments issues and understanding of how faith-based organisations work make us a suitable partner. The framework of our support is a ‘cultures sensitive approach’ and ‘participation’.
DD Connect is run by two members: Ddungu Charles and Josefien Van Olmen. 

1) Ddungu Charles, PhD, is a theologian and expert in Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation (PME).. After his doctoral research in practical theology at the Catholic University of Leuven and a Master in Cultures and Development at the same University, he worked as a Planning, Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning advisor at Mensen met een Missie in the Hague. Before that, he served as a pastoral worker in Brussels and in Tabora in Tanzania, where he integrated church work with development. His areas of interest and expertise are the relationship between cultures, religions and development, qualitative and participatory PME methods, and facilitating and training.  He is currently working as a part time spiritual care provider to patients and their families in Westeinde and Antoniushove Hospitals in the Hague. 

2) Josefien, MD, MPH works as a Health Systems Scientist at the Department of Public Health at the Institute of Tropical Medicine in Antwerp. She has worked for faith-based health care organisations in East and Central Africa. Her areas of expertise are Health Systems Analysis & Strengthening, Organisation of Care for Chronic Diseases, Health Service Delivery, and Methodology for Evaluation of Complex Interventions. Presently, she is in charge of a multi-country study research project on mobile phone support for self-management of diabetes patients.
